basics.name: Sanjana Nandi
basics.label: Software Engineer
basics.summary: Software engineer with a B.S. and M.Eng. in Computer Science from Cornell University (GPA: 3.5), bringing robust experience in Python and Java development, image processing, and full-stack systems. Proven success contributing to enterprise-scale projects at L3Harris Technologies, Stanford Linear Accelerator Center LCLS, and Amazon's open-source initiative.

work.name: Cornell Cup Robotics
highlights: Led a team of 10 engineers to deliver scalable, modular software systems that supported classroom deployments of XRP across diverse hardware platforms.
Improved hardware-software communication latency by 35% through a redesigned USB serial protocol, enhancing real-time responsiveness.
Reduced onboarding time by 25% via architectural refactoring and comprehensive documentation.
Served as liaison to external partners including SparkFun and Raspberry Pi, aligning R&D priorities with hardware constraints.
Presented XRP innovations to 5+ U.S. senators and senior industry leaders at the national XRP Consortium summit in Washington, D.C.

work.name: Cornell Cup Robotics
highlights: Contributed to core software components of the XRP educational robotics platform used globally in 180+ countries.
Developed embedded software on Raspberry Pi Pico W (MicroPython) and Pi Zero W (Python), implementing custom USB serial communication to enable real-time sensor data and LCD feedback.
Built React.js and Flask-based teacher dashboards for monitoring and controlling robot fleets in the classroom.
Collaborated closely with electrical and mechanical teams to integrate hardware and software subsystems.
Documented system architecture and created design diagrams to support development and onboarding.

work.name: L3Harris Technologies
highlights: Created synthetic satellite imagery using DIRSIG, Python, and OpenCV to help train computer vision models for object detection
Made the data generation process 90% faster by figuring out when certain 3D objects could be reused across similar scenes
Used feature comparison techniques (like cosine similarity) to ensure the reused-image data still looked and performed like fully generated scenes

work.name: Amazon Open Source Contributor Initiative
highlights: Selected for a competitive open-source mentorship program (5% acceptance rate) led by Amazon engineers
Contributed to the OpenSearch Neural Search plugin, improving dense vector-based neural retrieval functionality
Gained hands-on experience with large-scale distributed systems, Git-based workflows, and Java development
Collaborated with open-source maintainers and engineering mentors in an agile development environment

work.name: L3Harris Technologies
highlights: Developed Python tool to streamline quality control for satellite imagery in ML data pipelines
Implemented automated filtering of low-quality images using computer vision techniques
Generated internal API documentation with Sphinx to support developer productivity
Delivered final presentation to technical leadership; tools remain in active use
Recognized for independent execution and consistent team engagement

work.name: L3Harris Technologies
highlights: Evaluate OpenCV image processing routines and machine learning backends (TensorFlow, PyTorch, Gluon, and Caffe) to recommend optimal solutions for future remote sensing systems
Facilitated better time keeping in remote sensing applications by documenting the handling of leap seconds and Earth Orientation Parameters (EOP) in Astropy

work.name: Stanford Linear Accelerator Center LCLS
highlights: Performed a parametric study on the Cori supercomputer using Dragonfly to evaluate how particle species, size, and sampling rate affect single-particle reconstruction quality
Cut reconstruction runtime by 50% by modeling tradeoffs between image quality and compute performance, and optimizing parallelization settings (MPI/OpenMP)
Assessed reconstruction outcomes using statistical metrics (RMS change, log-likelihood, mutual information) to guide configuration tuning

work.name: Stanford Linear Accelerator Center LCLS
highlights: Analyzed soft X-ray beamline data to determine the degree of linear polarization of LCLS free-electron laser (FEL) radiation
Developed Python scripts using NumPy and lmfit for curve fitting, intensity normalization, and preliminary error modeling
ontributed to method development for polarization analysis and identified factors for future optimization, including filter interference and background correction

courses: Activities and societies: Cornell Cup Robotics
Activities and societies: Cornell Cup Robotics

Activities and societies: FIRST Robotics Competition Team 2643, Networking Specialist of Cyber Patriot team, Wind EnsembleActivities and societies: FIRST Robotics Competition Team 2643, Networking Specialist of Cyber Patriot team, Wind Ensemble
Served as Programming Lead for FRC Team 2643, where I helped develop control systems that contributed to the team's first qualification for the FIRST World Championships.
Worked closely with other subteams during fast-paced build seasons and participated in community STEM outreach.
Was a Networking Specialist in the CyberPatriot program, completing CCNA coursework and gaining experience with network security tools such as Wireshark, Cisco Packet Tracer, and Cisco CLI.

projects.name: Quantum Computing
projects.summary: Quantum computing is the use of quantum-mechanical phenomena such as superposition and entanglement to perform computation. Computers that perform quantum computations are known as quantum computers.
highlights: Quantum Teleportation
Quantum Cryptography
